ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the supply and demand sides of microeconomics.

I came into this course with no knowledge of economics. None. Leaving this course, I feel like I have a great general understanding of supply curves, demand curves, and equilibriums. I know how to apply graphs to the economic world, and I appreciate the seminar version of this class.
Microeconomic principles including labor and production side of economics.

In theory basic economic functions. In practice, a lot about random companies and professor life stories. What we learned in class was never enough to understand the material, the textbook did not help at all, and professor and TA office hours did not do much to supplement either. Most of what I learned was from ACDC Economics, without which I have no doubt I would have failed.k
Microeconomics
It was my first economics course and it was a great overview.
I have developed a different mindset to evaluate matters from an economic perspective, which is very valuable.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the material could go slower. I often had a hard time following lecture. I also think either more Psets or more tests would have been nice as the exams were very stressful

This course as a seminar is strong in that I can get specific questions answered almost immediately. The professor is outstanding in aiding understanding. The office hours are stellar, alongside all the resources. I would say the tests are tough, but expected in regard to economics. It's an amazing course regardless.
strengths, tolga. weaknesses, its hard
This course covers a lot of microeconomic theory to build a strong foundation for understanding how factors of markets affect one another.

The class time. On the first day of class, we were informed there would be  a third mandatory class meeting Friday mornings (a change still not reflected in course information or room reservations), and despite spending close to 5hrs/week in class and office hours, it felt like a large chunk of the time was often not spent on Econ, which made learning material very difficult, and towards the end, very rushed. It would be nice if the TA were more accessible outside of the one monday office hour too.
Able to ask a lot of questions but the class is very competitive since it's graded on a curve so most people don't want help each other out.
It was a great overview course. Could be good to receive more feedback before the final, though

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If they actually want to learn microeconomics then yes

Yes. It's a great way to fulfill a QR distributional, and I think the professor made the course what it is. It's important to understand financials in the greater world, and I find the study applicable. The course was accessible for students, regardless of what information they came in with, which for me, was close to nothing. The seminar is a bit stress-inducing because of a less forgiving curve, but overall, I think it was worth it.
Yes

Take literally any other microecon intro course or watch ACDC econ and take a higher one to begin. Feedback is nonexistent, there is little understanding given to students, and multiple full-length classes will feel like it was for naught. I do think the material itself is definitely worth learning, but if you want to learn it, this class isn't for you
No I'd say Econ 110 is better because there is more room for error on your exams
yes! It was. a good foundation and really helped me know whether or not I want to take future micro courses. (The answer is no, but I appreciated knowing that)
